questions.question: A 30-year-old truck driver presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. Onexamination, a single ulcer with an indurated base was found. An image of the tissue sectionis shown below. Identify the staining method.316
questions.explanation: The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painlessulcer with indurated base points towards the diagnosis of syphilis.Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmittedinfection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis.It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy.Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods.•Fontana's method is used on smear• Levaditi's method is used for tissue sectionsThe clinical manifestations of syphilis include:Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papulethat rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginousconsistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres.The chancre generally heals within 4-6 weeks (range, 2-12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy maypersist for months.Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions andgeneralized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionallypustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss,malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (orlater/unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the325classic iritis or uveitis.Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latentsyphilis is defined as that of 1 year's duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seedthe bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant womaninfect the fetus in utero.mayNeurosyphilis: The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal,meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aorticregurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or"snuffles"; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-rayexamination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice,thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention(CDC):• Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),•Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor responseto therapy (RPR or VDRL)• Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS,TPHA, EIA/CIA)Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

questions.question: What type of motility is shown by Treponema pallidum?
questions.explanation: Treponema pallidum show corkscrew motility, i.e movement by rotation around the long axis.The characteristic feature of spirochetes is the presence of endoflagella, situated between theouter membrane and cell wall, that facilitates this movement.326OMARROW

questions.question: A 32-year-old pregnant lady tests VDRL positive at her 1st-trimester antenatal check-up. AnFTA-ABS confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is a false statement about theorganism causing this disease?

options.A: It cannot be cultured in vitro
options.B: Endoflagella is in the periplasmic space.
options.C: Humans are the only known natural hosts

questions.explanation: VDRL positive status is suggestive of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. Fluorescenttreponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) is a confirmatory test.Reiter's strain is a cultivable, non-pathogenic treponeme, showing morphological and antigenicsimilarities with T.pallidum. It is widely used as the antigen in group-specific treponemal tests forthe diagnosis of syphilis.Nichol's strain is virulent and non-cultivable in artificial media. However, it can be grown in cellculture through serial passage in live rabbit testes.

questions.question: A patient had a solitary, painless penile ulcer 2 months back. Now, he presents with ageneralized maculopapular rash over the body. What is the sensitivity of VDRL at this stage ofthe disease?
questions.explanation: The sensitivity of VDRL is 100% in secondary syphilis. History of solitary painless ulcer with ageneralized maculopapular rash is consistent with secondary syphilis.The VDRL test becomes positive 4–5 weeks after exposure to T. pallidum and 1-2 weeks after theappearance of the chancre.The VDRL test is a highly sensitive test. The sensitivity of the test depends on the stage of thedisease:• Primary syphilis- 60-75%• Secondary syphilis- 100%•High antibody titers may be found in patients developing gummatous lesions and neurovascularor cardiovascular complications.•Tertiary syphilis- usually negative•Negative test:327•Early primary syphilis•Latent acquired syphilis•• Late congenital syphilisSecondary syphilis is the most infective stage in the course of the illness. The patient may presentwith a roseolar or papular skin rash, condyloma lata, and mucous patches.The image below shows lesions of secondary syphilis.

questions.question: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the serological tests of syphilis?

options.A: Rapid plasma reagin test is a group specific treponemal test
options.B: VDRL test is the test of choice for response to therapy
options.C: VDRL is the test of choice for examining CSF
options.D: Treponemal tests are likely to remain reactive even after adequate therapy

questions.explanation: RPR is a non-specific test. It uses the VDRL antigen (cardiolipin) containing carbon particles.Hence, results can be seen by the naked eye, whereas VDRL requires a microscope forvisualization of flocculation.The test of choice for monitoring response to treatment and for examining CSF is VDRLThe test of choice for syphilis screening is RPR.After treatment, in early syphilis,• Non-treponemal tests- titers decline or become non-reactive•• Treponemal tests- remain reactiveFor diagnosis of syphilis, a 2 test approach is used i.e., screening with an NTT (non-treponemaltest) which includes either VDRL or RPR. Confirmation of syphilis is done by a treponemal test,most commonly by TPHA (Treponema pallidum hemagglutination test).Follow-up is done using NTT (as treponemal tests remains positive for years after treatment).

questions.question: A55-year old man was brought to the OPD with complaints of rapid decline in cognition,impaired position, and vibratory sense. There is a history of sporadic short-term relationshipswith many promiscuous sexual partners. Romberg's sign is positive and bilateral ArgyllRobertson pupils are seen on checking for pupillary reflex. Which of the following is theinvestigation of choice?
questions.explanation: 328The clinical scenario given above with a positive sexual history, Romberg test, and ArgyllRobertson pupils is suggestive of neurosyphilis. The investigation of choice for neurosyphilisis VDRL.The CSF VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic ofneurosyphilis.Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:• Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/µL).• Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).⚫ CSF VDRL reactivity.•

questions.question: You treated a case of secondary syphilis with a single dose of benzathine penicillin-G 2.4million IU IM. What follow-up advice would you give for the assessment of the patient's318response to treatment?

options.A: Follow up with VDRL after 6 months and 12 months
options.B: Follow up with VDRL after 3 months and 6 months
options.C: Follow up with TPHA after 6 months and 12 months
options.D: Follow up with TPHA after 3 months and 6 months

questions.explanation: The investigation used to assess response to treatment in syphilis is VDRL. In the case ofsecondary syphilis, follow-up VDRL should be done at 6 months and 12 months.VDRL and RPR become negative after adequate treatment whereas specific treponemal testsremain positive indefinitely despite treatment.Guidelines for follow up:• Patients with primary or secondary syphilis should be examined 6 and 12 months aftertreatment.• Patients with latent or late syphilis should be examined at 6, 12, and 24 months after treatment.

questions.question: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestational age tested VDRL positive but negative forspecific treponemal tests. What is your interpretation?
questions.explanation: Pregnancy can give rise to false-positive VDRL.Biological false-positive (BFP) reactions are defined as positive reactions obtained innon-specific treponemal tests (RPR, VDRL) with negative results in specific treponemal tests, inthe absence of past or present treponemal infections and not caused by technical faults.

questions.question: A 2-month-old infant presented with a runny nose and bullous lesions on the skin and legs.Her X-ray (given below) showed features suggestive of periostitis. Which of the following isthe initial investigation of choice?
questions.explanation: The newborn baby has characteristic signs and symptoms of congenital syphilis. Periostitis is ahallmark of skeletal manifestation. VDRL or RPR is the initial investigation of choice incongenital syphilis.The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or "snuffles"; mucocutaneouslesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones;hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.All neonates born to mothers who have reactive nontreponemal and treponemal test resultsshould be evaluated with a quantitative nontreponemal serologic test (RPR or VDRL) performed329on the neonate's serum, because umbilical cord blood can become contaminated with maternalblood and yield a false-positive result.FTA-ABS or TPHA is used for confirmation of syphilis in a patient with reactive RPR or VDRLtest.T. pallidum cannot be detected by culture.

questions.explanation: Epidemic relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia recurrentis and is transmitted by louse.330Endemic relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia duttoni, Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia parkeri, etc, andis transmitted by ticks.

questions.question: Which one of the following micro-organisms uses antigenic variation as a major means ofevading the host immune system?320
questions.explanation: Borrelia recurrentis uses antigenic variation as a major means of evading the host immunesystem. It causes relapsing fever.Borrelia readily undergoes antigenic variations in vivo and this is believed to be the reason for theoccurrence of relapses in the disease. Antigenic variations occur because of DNA rearrangementsin linear plasmids present in borrelia.

questions.question: A 23 year old presented with fever, myalgia, and skin lesion as shown in the image. What isthe causative organism for the above condition?
questions.explanation: The image shows erythema migrans, seen in Lyme disease. It is caused by Borrelia Burgdoferi.The lesion has a target center with partial central clearing and a bright red outer border. Itusually begins as a red macule or papule at the site of the tick bite.The tick implicated is the black-legged tick, Ixodes scapularis, shown in the image below.331The most severe manifestation of Lyme disease is Lyme neuroborreliosis (LNB), reported in10-15% of individuals with localized erythema migrans. The activation of the inflammatoryresponse in LNB contributes to the pathogenesis of a broad spectrum of neurologic disorders.

questions.question: Following a flood, there is an outbreak of fever. Water samples from various sources arebeing studied for pathogens. The bacteria shown in the given image was isolated as apotential cause of disease. Which of the following animals is the most important reservoir ofthese organisms?321JEOL SEI 5.0kV x17,0001pm WD 8mm
questions.explanation: The electron micrograph shows the spirochete, Leptospira interrogans, which causes thewater-borne disease, leptospirosis. Rats are the most important reservoir.Transmission of leptospires may follow direct contact with urine, blood, or tissue from an infectedanimal or exposure to environmental contamination.

questions.question: A farmer who works in paddy fields presented with fever, intense myalgia, and hematochezia.Lab investigations showed sharply elevated creatinine levels and high liver enzymes. What isthe causative organism?
questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Weil's disease which is caused by leptospira.Long hours of working in a field with water (paddy field), is a high-risk factor for the developmentof leptospirosis.Weil's syndrome is the severe form of leptospirosis that encompasses the triad of hemorrhage,jaundice, and acute kidney injury.The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

questions.question: At a relief camp in Karnataka, a few people developed fever, myalgia, and conjunctivalsuffusion. Rapid diagnostic IgM ELISA tests performed in the field showed leptospirosis.Which of the following culture media can be used to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) media is the culture medium used forleptospira.332Other culture media that can be used are Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.The image below shows EMJH medium, with Dinger's ring/zone. The growth of the leptospires isat a maximum density at this zone. It is identified as an area of increased turbidity, beneath thesurface of the semi-solid medium. It is the zone of optimum oxygen tension for the growth of thebacteria.EMJH medium©MARROWDinger's ring

questions.question: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.explanation: History of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis(Weil's disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.Serotype-specific tests:•Microscopic agglutination test•Macroscopic agglutination testOption A: Widal test is used to screen for typhoid feverOption C: Weil-Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial feversOption D: Paul-Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion,icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis.Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with milddisease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache,abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves,abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.333Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classicpresentation of the severe disease called Weil's syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage,jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physicalexamination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation /relativebradycardia can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin,ampicillin, or ceftriaxone.The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis.Progression of leptospirosisAppropriateWeek 12time scaleIncubation periodAcutestage2-20 daysInoculationfeverPresent inBloodCSFUrineAntibody titers€HighLow"Negative"Laboratory investigations BloodPhasesCultureSerology34months-yearsyearsConvalescentstageUveitis? Interstitial nephritisHReservoir hostConvalescent shedderNormal responseTiters declineat varying ratesEarly treatmentAnamnesticDelayedCSFUrineLeptospiremia→Leptospiremiaand immunityOMARROWLeptospira are actively motile organisms and are best seen using a dark-field microscope. They arethin, tightly coiled, and flexible spirochetes with one end forming a hook. Diagnosis is bymicroscopic agglutination test.Transmission occurs through cuts or breaks in the skin and mucous membranes (conjunctival andoral mucosa). Several outbreaks have been reported that resulted from exposure to floodwaterscontaminated by urine from infected animals. The organism enters the bloodstream and lodges inthe parenchymatous organs (liver and kidneys) leading to hemorrhage and necrosis of the tissue334causing dysfunction of the organs.The lifecycle of Leptospira is shown below.InfectLifecycle of LeptospiraReservoirRat, dog, horseCARRYLeptospiraUrineContaminatedwater,soil, foodOMARROWUrineSplashcontaminationof eyes with waterinfected with urineIngestion ofcontaminatedfood/waterWoundexposureIllness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. The stages are:•Acute leptospiremic phase- the organism can be cultured from blood.• Resolving immune phase- the organism can be cultured from urine.The stages may not be clinically distinguishable.Other options:Option A - Chikungunya is a viral disease that presents with saddle-back fever, conjunctivalsuffusion, and photophobia. Migratory arthralgia, especially involving small joints may also beseen. A maculopapular or petechial rash is frequently seen on the trunk.Option C - Dengue hemorrhagic fever is a form of severe dengue with bleeding manifestations.Evidence of plasma leakage and thrombocytopenia is also generally seen.Option D - Encephalitis due to Hepatitis A is seen in fulminant hepatitis, a rare complication.Patients present with confusion, disorientation, ascites, and edema.335
